I want to thank them and all the Newtown

very proud of him I want to thank the

and I want to thank the people of

and as a society we decided that we have
to change we must we must change
I noticed that Nicole and others refer
to that day as 12 14 for these families
it was a day that changed everything and
I know many of you in Newtown wondered

it feels like it's been years since she

what happened that day just fade away
we're not going anywhere she said we are
here we are going to be here and I know
that she speaks for everybody in Newtown
everybody who was impacted and Newtown
we want you to know that we're here with

we can't forget your families still

so many of you have mobilized and

so I want to be clear you the families
of Newtown people across Connecticut you

your determination made that happen
obviously the elected leaders did an

and by the way Connecticut's not alone

these are all states but share an awful

it's the horror of mass killings or

that's too common in too many

don't contradict each other we can pass

and protect our rights so Connecticut's

Congress to do the same
now's the time for Congress to do the

now back in January just a few months

we have to tell Congress it's time to

we have to tell Congress it's time to

we have to tell Congress it's time to

now I know that some of these proposals

all of them deserve a vote consider
background checks over the past 20 years
background checks have kept more than 2
million dangerous people from getting
their hands on a gun a group of police
officers in Colorado told me last week
that thanks to background checks they've
been able to stop convicted murders
folks under restraining orders for
committing violent domestic abuse from
buying a gun in some cases they've
actually arrested the person as they
were coming to purchase the gun so we
know that background checks can work but
the problem is loopholes in the current
law let so many people avoid background
checks all together that's not safe it
doesn't make sense if you're a
law-abiding citizen and you go through a

you expect other people to play by the
same rules if you're a law-abiding gun
seller wouldn't you want to know you're
not selling your gun to someone who's
likely to commit a crime
shouldn't we make it harder not easier
for somebody who's convicted of domestic

it turns out ninety percent of americans
think so ninety percent of americans

if our democracies working the way it's

they're not just saying they'll vote no

we need a vote

sometimes when you watch
sometimes when you watch cable news or

he was on his way to school he was

was in the right place at the right time
and he still got shot the kids at Sandy

they were exactly where they were

surely we can reconcile those two things
surely America doesn't have to be

is the time to get engaged now is the

I've heard Nicole talk about what her

now if Nicole can summon the courage to

if there's even one step we can take to

shouldn't we be taking that step
if there's just one thing we can do to
